question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency room by the police after a fall. The patient smells of alcohol and is slurring his words. You find out that he has recently been fired from his job as a salesperson for months of tardiness and poor performance. The police tell you that his girlfriend, who was there at the time of the fall, mentioned that the patient has been struggling with alcohol for at least a year. Upon physical examination, the patient becomes agitated and starts yelling. He accuses his ex-boss of being a cocaine addict and says he couldnвЂ™t keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine. What psychiatric defense mechanisms is the patient demonstrating?. If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: A 24-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by police after a fall; he smelled of alcohol, was slurring his words, had recently been fired from a salesperson position for months of tardiness and poor performance, and, per police report, his girlfriend indicated he had been struggling with alcohol for at least a year. During physical examination he became agitated and started yelling, accusing his ex-boss of being a cocaine addict and asserting he could not keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine. These observed behaviors map onto two classic ego defenses. First, projection is evidenced by the patient’s attribution of a substance misuse problem (cocaine use) to his ex-boss, thereby externalizing unacceptable impulses and conflicts consistent with his own ongoing alcohol misuse. Second, rationalization is demonstrated by his provision of a socially plausible yet inaccurate account for occupational failure—namely, that he could not match a cocaine user’s sales performance—rather than acknowledging the documented proximal contributors of alcohol misuse, tardiness, and poor performance. Taken together, the clinical vignette supports the conclusion: Projection and Rationalization.
content.source_2: The clinical presentation—a 24-year-old man brought in by police after a fall, smelling of alcohol and slurring his words, recently terminated from a salesperson role after months of tardiness and poor performance, with collateral from his girlfriend indicating at least a year of struggling with alcohol, and becoming agitated during examination while accusing his ex-boss of cocaine use and claiming he could not keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine—illustrates a constellation of maladaptive defense mechanisms. Denial is reflected in the patient’s failure to accept the implications of his problematic alcohol use despite concrete adverse consequences (job loss and police involvement). Projection is apparent insofar as he is attributing his own cocaine use to his boss rather than admitting to it himself, thereby displacing unacceptable substance-related impulses onto another target. Rationalization is evidenced by his attempt to justify tardiness and poor performance through an externally focused, seemingly plausible narrative—blaming an allegedly cocaine-addicted superior—rather than taking responsibility for alcohol-related impairment. The pattern is consistent with Denial, Projection, Rationalization.
content.source_3: In this case, a 24-year-old man was transported to the emergency room by police following a fall; he smelled of alcohol, was slurring his speech, had been fired from his salesperson job for months of tardiness and poor performance, and, according to police, his girlfriend reported he had been struggling with alcohol for at least a year. On examination he became agitated, yelled, accused his ex-boss of being a cocaine addict, and stated he could not keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine. Two defense mechanisms are salient. Denial—defined as the refusal to accept reality or fact—is evidenced by his lack of acknowledgment that his alcohol problem underlies his recent job loss and related difficulties despite clear temporal and causal associations. Projection—attributing one’s unacceptable thoughts, feelings, or motives to another—is demonstrated by his displacement of substance-related concerns onto his ex-boss, whom he accuses of using cocaine. The diagnostic inference is Denial and Projection.
content.source_4: A 24-year-old man, brought to the emergency department by police after a fall and found to smell of alcohol with slurred speech, had been terminated from a salesperson position for months of tardiness and poor performance; collateral from his girlfriend indicated he had been struggling with alcohol for at least a year. During the physical examination, he became agitated and started yelling, accused his ex-boss of being a cocaine addict, and stated he could not keep up sales percentages compared to someone using cocaine. Within a probabilistic framework applied to individuals with substance abuse problems, the prior probability of each of two defenses—projection and rationalization—can be approximately 10%. The accusatory stance toward the ex-boss, given the context and lack of evidence, is a prototypical instance of projection (attributing one’s unacceptable thoughts or behaviors to another), which increases the posterior probability to 40%. His explanatory claim that impaired job performance derived from an inability to match an allegedly cocaine-using supervisor’s sales figures constitutes rationalization, a justification strategy using plausible but incorrect reasons, further increasing the posterior probability to 60%. The aggregate pattern supports the final judgment: Projection, Rationalization.
